case_vignette: A 49-year-old man comes to the phys   ician because of tender, red nodules that appeared on his chest 3 days ago. Three weeks ago, he had similar symptoms in his    right low   er limb and another episode in his le ft foot; both epis   odes resolved spontaneously. He also has  diarrhea and has had a poor appetite for 1 month. He has a history of dry cough and join   t pain, for which he takes albuterol and aspir in as needed. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years. He does not drink alcohol. Physical    exa  mination shows a linear, erythematous lesion o   n the right anterior chest wall, through wh  ich a cord-like structure can be palpated. The lungs    are clear   to auscultation. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and non   - distended. Examination of the legs is normal. An ultrasound of the legs shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is  the most appropriate next step in    diagnosis of   the underlying condition?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have tender, red nodules on my chest that appeared 3 days ago, and I've been having diarrhea and a poor appetite for a month.
Have you experienced any fever or joint pain recently?
I have been experiencing joint pain.
Do you have any pre-existing conditions or have you been diagnosed with diseases affecting your immune system?
I have a history of dry cough and joint pain.
Have you had any recent infections, travel history, or use of new medications prior to the onset of your symptoms?
No, I have not had any recent infections, travel history, or use of new medications prior to the onset of these symptoms.
Do you have a family history of autoimmune diseases or inflammatory conditions?
I did not mention any family history of autoimmune diseases or inflammatory conditions.
Final Diagnosis: Erythema nodosum
